dt: {bc}to find out or learn with certainty

dt.t: trying to {wi}ascertain{/wi} the cause of the fire
information that can be easily {wi}ascertained{/wi} on the Internet

pt: {sc}discover{/sc} {sc}ascertain{/sc} {sc}determine{/sc} {sc}unearth{/sc} {sc}learn{/sc} mean to find out what one did not previously know. {sc}discover{/sc} may apply to something requiring exploration or investigation or to a chance encounter.
{sc}ascertain{/sc} implies effort to find the facts or the truth proceeding from awareness of ignorance or uncertainty.

pt.t: attempts to {it}ascertain{/it} the population of the region

pt: {sc}determine{/sc} emphasizes the intent to establish the facts definitely or precisely.

pt.t: unable to {it}determine{/it} the origin of the word

pt: {sc}unearth{/sc} implies bringing to light something forgotten or hidden.
{sc}learn{/sc} may imply acquiring knowledge with little effort or conscious intention (as by simply being told) or it may imply study and practice.

quotes.t: We look at digital media—images, audio and video—and we try to {qword}ascertain{/qword} whether or not they've been manipulated. We use mathematical and computational techniques to detect alterations in them.

Currently, an official trying to {qword}ascertain{/qword} road damage in the aftermath of an earthquake might have to keep one eye on the TV news while listening to both radio traffic reports and the police scanner. Since most of these data are available in digital form, the software could take them all in, process them and present a report outlining the best evacuation routes.
With an equation linking the money wage to prices, the degree of inflation could be {qword}ascertained{/qword}.

et: Middle English {it}acertainen{/it} to inform, give assurance to, from Anglo-French {it}acerteiner{/it}, from {it}a-{/it} (from Latin {it}ad-{/it}) + {it}certein, certain{/it} certain
shortdef: to find out or learn with certainty
to make certain, exact, or precise
